H0.text: Nitrogen atoms are different sizes, which explains why nitrogen can exist in many compounds, as seen in simple nonliving substances such as air and in complex molecules in living organisms such as DNA.

H1.text: Nitrogen atoms are different ages explains why nitrogen can exist in many compounds, because nitrogen is present in simple nonliving substances such as air and in complex molecules in living organisms such as DNA.

H2.text: Nitrogen atoms can bond to different atoms, which explains why nitrogen can exist in many compounds, including simple nonliving substances such as air and complex molecules in living organisms such as DNA.

H3.text: Nitrogen atoms have different amounts of energy, explaining why nitrogen can exist in many compounds found in simple nonliving substances such as air and in complex molecules in living organisms such as DNA.

A4.text: Nitrogen shares with both its horizontal neighbours a preference for forming multiple bonds, typically with carbon, oxygen, or other nitrogen atoms, through pπ–pπ interactions.
